title: Erlang's not about lightweight processes and message passing
dot:

(Not about lightweight processes & message passing)"];Background[label="Background
- Started as Prolog library
- Goal: Reliable distributed systems
- Developed at Ericsson
- Open-sourced in 1998"];JoeArmstrong[label="Joe Armstrong
- PhD Thesis: 'Making reliable distributed systems in the presence of software errors'
- Focus on Behaviours"];Behaviours[label="Behaviours
- gen_server, gen_event, gen_fsm, supervisor, application, release
- Provide structure for reliable systems"];Supervisors[label="Supervisors
- Process monitoring & restart strategies
- 'Let it crash' philosophy"];Testing[label="Testing & Correctness
- Simulation testing
- Formal verification"];Contributing[label="Contributing Ideas
- Fast event loops
- Async I/O
- Supervisors
- Hot code swapping"];MainIdea->Background;Background->JoeArmstrong;JoeArmstrong->Behaviours;Behaviours->Supervisors;Supervisors->Testing;Testing->Contributing;}

title: Apple: The only big tech giant going against the job cuts tide
dot: digraph{subgraph cluster_tech_recessions{label="Tech Recessions";"Dotcom Bust (2001)"->"2009 Recession";"2009 Recession"->"Recent Times";}"Amazon"->"Dotcom Bust (2001)"[label="Revenue declined by 13%, laid off 13%"];"Amazon"->"2002-2003"[label="Continued headcount reduction"];"Amazon"->"2004"[label="Revenue growth above 30%"];"Apple"->"Dotcom Bust (2001)"[label="Revenue declined by 33%, no layoffs, slowed hiring"];"Apple"->"2002-2003"[label="Continued with slow hiring"];"Apple"->"2004"[label="Revenue growth caught up"];"Microsoft"->"2009 Recession"[label="Revenue growth slowed, laid off 6% (5,000 people)"];"Apple"->"2009 Recession"[label="Revenue growth slowed to 15%, no layoffs, slowed hiring"];"Apple"->"Recent Times"[label="Revenue declined by 8%, no layoffs"];subgraph cluster_hiring_comparison{label="Big Tech Hiring Comparison";"Google"->"Headcount Growth";"Meta"->"Headcount Growth";"Microsoft"->"Headcount Growth";"Apple"->"Headcount Growth"[label="Lowest headcount growth since 2018"];}"Apple"->"Tim Cook as CEO (2011 - present)"[label="Stable headcount growth, irrespective of profit"];"Apple"->"2020 - 2022"[label="Did not grow headcount as fast as others"];"Apple"->"2020 - 2021"[label="Hired more than normal for attrition, some teams struggled to fill"];"Apple"->"January 2023"[label="Some positions closed, but not widespread"];}
